title: Phone Number Enumeration
vulnerability_information_html:
I discovered it is possible to retrieve all Uber's customer's cell phone numbers using an API endpoint.

While going through a sign up form, I noticed that the page was making an ajax call to an API to validate the email address being entered and to make sure it doesn't already belong to an account. I began experimenting with the API and discovered that it will do the same type of validation for mobile numbers.

Response With Unused Mobile Number

Response With Used Mobile Number (my cell number)

Using this information, it is very easy to loop through numbers and generate a list of Uber's customer's mobile numbers. I created a simple proof-of-concept in Python showing how this can be done and attached it to this report. uber_number.py (F93853)

This screenshot shows the results of my PoC script after running through a small range of numbers above and below my wife's cell phone number. The 8054528808 number is hers. I have no relationship to the other numbers. Other than checking around my wife's and my cell phone numbers, I did not attempt to extract any other numbers or information.

Here is another screenshot after running the PoC script for numbers just above and below my number (4155083235).

Using this information, an attacker could launch a massive phishing campaign or just harass Uber customers. It would probably also be bad PR if someone were to dump all Uber's customer's cell phone numbers out on to the Internet.

Requiring a CSRF token in the API request would slow the process down considerably, but wouldn't completely eliminate it. Maybe requiring a CSRF token and adding some rate limiting might do it.

Thanks!

  • Seth

activities.message:
I think I forgot to include the API endpoint. It's located here: https://get.uber.com/validate_field/
You can check it using Curl from a Linux console:

```
curl -i "https://get.uber.com/validate_field/" -d "field=mobile&mobile=4155083235"
```

activities.message:
Thanks for this report.

We do have rate-limiting but because of certain cases where large user bases share IPs, the rate limiting is high enough that you might not have seen it kick in. In our testing we received a `429: Too Many Requests` response from the server after about 500 requests. We'll be closing this as informative but we encourage you to continue searching for security vulnerabilities in our software. 

Thanks and good luck in your future bug hunting.

activities.message:
Hi @bugtriage-rob, 

Thanks for looking into the issue. It looks like the API endpoint was just changed to no longer indicate if a mobile number is attached to an account or not. Is that correct? Thanks! 

- Seth
activities.markdown_message:

  • Seth

activities.message: Hey @megocode3 this report wasn't `Triaged` so our engineering team hasn't looked at it yet/made any changes based off of it. Let me know if you have any further questions - thanks!
activities.markdown_message: Hey @megocode3 this report wasn't Triaged so our engineering team hasn't looked at it yet/made any changes based off of it. Let me know if you have any further questions - thanks!

@mandatoryuber,

These are the API responses I received from https://get.uber.com/validate_field just before I submitted my report and the response from the exact same request just after my report was closed. Screenshots have been attached. The API endpoint has definitely been changed. Is it possible that the sudden increase in traffic to this endpoint brought some attention to it from outside the security team?

API Response Prior To Submitting My Report
{"field":"mobile","message":"Mobile number has already been registered","reason":"mobile_duplicate","status_code":406}

API Response Immediately After My Report Was Closed
{"field":"mobile","status_code":200}

activities.message:
Hey @megocode3, sorry for the delay.

We typically have meetings a few times a month to discuss public disclosure requests, after that we will let you know. Thanks!
